questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
• Muscles of mastication are involved in the given condition.
  • All the muscles of mastication are supplied by mandibular nerve.
  • Mandibular nerve passes through foramen ovale.
  • Structures passing through foramen ovale (MALE)

→ Mandibular Nerve

→Accessory meningeal artery

→Lesser Petrosal Nerve

→Emissary veins

choices.text: Radial nerve in the radial groove

questions.text: FINGER DROP WITH NO WRIST DROP is caused by lesion of:
questions.solution:
• Finger drop with NO wrist drop is Seen in Posterior interosseous nerve injury.
  • In injury to posterior interosseous nerve, wrist drop is not seen because ECRL muscle will be spared.
  • Finger drop WITH wrist drop is Seen in injury of Radial nerve in the radial groove

questions.text: From which of the following is nucleus pulposus formed?
questions.solution:
• A – Neural Tube
  • B – Paraxial Mesoderm
  • C – Notochord
  • D – Intermediate Mesoderm
  • Remnant of Notochord – Nucleus Pulposus, Apical ligament of Dens and Membrana tectoria.

questions.text: Each of the following has an attachment to scapula except
questions.solution:
1. Pectoralis major – Attached to Clavicle and sternum for origin and Bicipital grove of humerus for insertion
  2. Pectoralis minor – Attached to scapula (coracoid process) for insertion
  3. Biceps brachii – Short head – Attached to scapula (coracoid process) for origin – Long head – Attached to scapula (Supraglenoid tubercle) for origin
  4. Triceps – Long head – Attached to scapula (Supraglenoid tubercle) for origin

questions.text: Damage to the structure producing the elevation marked 'X' leads to paralysis of which of the following muscle?
questions.solution: • Marked elevation is Facial colliculus which is produced by Facial nerve (internal genu around abducent nucleus), so muscle paralysed will be risorius.

questions.text: All are correct regarding muscle supplied by long thoracic nerve except
questions.solution:
• Long thoracic nerve supplies Serratus anterior muscle.
  • Serratus anterior muscle helps in punching and pushing movemet ( Protration of Scapula).
  • Serratus anterior muscle also helps in overhead abduction of arm (> 90 degrees) along with trapezius muscle.
  • Injury to long throacic nerve leads of paralysis of serratus anterior muscel (Winging of Scapula )
  • Serratus anterior muscle originates from upper 8 ribs and inserts on medial border of scapula.

choices.text: Loss of sensation in dorsal forearm

questions.text: Fracture at arrow marked region results in
questions.solution:
• In the given image injury is at surgical neck of humerus leading to injury to axillary nerve passing posterior to that.
  • Axillary nerve supplies to deltoid muscle and teres minor muscle. Therefore imjury to axillary nerve leads to flat shoulder.
  • Axillary nerve also supplies to skin of upper lateral side of arm.

choices.text: Cut to spinal part of accessory nerve
Spread of infection to shoulder joint

questions.text: A 43 year old woman came with a large abscess in the middle of the right posterior triangle of the neck. The physician incised and drained the abscess. Five days later the patient noticed that she could not extend her right hand above her head to brush her hair. Which of the following are the signs and symptoms of additional harm -
questions.solution: • Superficial cut in the region of middle part of posterior triangle of neck will lead to injury to Spinal Accessory nerve, hence muscle supplied by it (trapezius) is paralysed. Therefore Shrugging of shoulder and Overhead Abduction of arm (for combing of hair) will be affected.

choices.text: Deep branch of transverse cervical artery & subscapular artery
Posterior circumflex humeral & circumflex scapular artery

questions.text: In obstruction of second part of axillay artery, the anostomosis between the following artery will maintain the blood supply of upper limb -
questions.solution: • In obstruction of second part of axillay artery, the anastomosis between the deep branch of transverse cervical artery (from first part of subclavian artery) & subscapular artery (from third part of Axillary artery) will maintain the blood supply of upper limb.

questions.text: Fascia marked 'X' in the image is derived from -
questions.solution:
• Fascia marked in the image is axillary sheath.
  • Axillary sheath is an extension prevertebral fascia which is a modification of deep cervical fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following brainstem nuclei is not derived from alar plate:
questions.solution:
• Neural tube has a dorsal alar plate which gives origin to the sensory nuclei and a ventral plate separated forming the motor nuclei.
  • The sensory and motor nuclei are separated from each other by the sulcus limitans.
  • The alar plate specifically later on becomes the dorsal gray of the spinal cord, and develops into the sensory nuclei of cranial nerves V, VII, VIII, IX, and
  • The inferior olivary nucleus, mesencephalic nucleus of V, and main sensory nucleus of V are also developed from this plate.

questions.text:
In the popliteal fossa which is of the following statements is True/false-
A. The popliteal fossa is bounded above by tendons of the hamstring muscles and below by the two heads of the gastrocnemius muscle
B. The deepest structure in the popliteal fossa is the popliteal artery
C. The popliteal and femoral vessels are continuous through the adductor hiatus
D. The common peroneal nerve passes superficially through the central protion of popliteal fossa
questions.solution:
• The common peroneal nerve appears in the popliteal fossa beneath the long head of the biceps femoris and slopes downward and laterally along the medial side of the tendon of biceps femoris up to the lateral angle of the fossa.
  • Here it crosses superficial to the plantaris, lateral head of gastrocnemius to reach the back of the head of fibula. it passes superficially through the central portion of popliteal fossa.
  • The Sciatic & Tibial nerve passes superficially through the central portion of popliteal fossa

questions.text: Arterial supply of motor area of cerebral cortex is:
questions.solution:
Anterior and middle cerebral artery

  • Motor area (4) is present in the precentral gyrus (frontal lobe).
  • Frontal lobe receives blood supply mainly from middle cerebral artery and partly from the anterior cerebral artery.
  • Middle cerebral territory in on the lateral surface, while anterior cerebral supplies a narrow strip close to the superior midline fissure

questions.text: Muscle marked in the image is supplied by
questions.solution:
• Muscle marked in the given image is dorsal interossei muscle (Bipinnate).
  • All the interossei are supplied by ulnar nerve (Deep Branch )

questions.text: Inability to abduct left eye with LMN facial palsy on same side. The lesion is in:
questions.solution:
Left pons

  • The abducent nucleus is present in the pons along with facial nucleus and both are damaged here.
  • These nuclei contain the lower motor neurons and hence the lesion here gives ipsilateral signs Hence, the lesion in the left pons leads to left facial palsy and inability to abduct the left eye laterally

choices.text: Lower part of pons near facial nucleus

questions.text: Principal Sensory Nucleus of Trigeminal is situated at:
questions.solution:
• Trigeminal nerve has 4 nuclei – 3 sensory and 1 motor.
  • 3 sensory nuclei are mesencephalic nucleus, chief sensory nucleus and spinal nucleus.
  • Chief sensory nucleus will be in upper part of pons.
  • Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal extends inferiorly into the medulla oblongata, whereas Mesencephalic nucleus extends into the mid-brain.

questions.text: Arrow marked structure in the given image contains-
questions.solution:
• Arrow marked structure in the given image is falx cerebri.
  • It consists of straight sinus. Straight sinus is a continuation of vein of galen or great cerebral vein.

choices.text: The inner layer contains granule and Golgi cells
Granule cells excite Purkinje, basket, stellate, and Golgi cells through parallel fibers
Purkinje cell convey the only output from cerebellar cortex
Granule cells receive afferent inhibitory fibers termed as mossy fibers

questions.text: Following statements describe the cells of cerebellar cortex. Choose the wrong statement:
questions.solution:
Granule cells receive afferent inhibitory fibers termed as mossy fibers

Mossy fibres are excitatory fibres, stimulating the Granule cells.

Granule cells then send the parallel fibres which will stimulate the remaining 4 cell types of the cerebellar cortex.

choices.text: Medial lemniscus on the right side of the pons
Dorsal columns on the right side of the spinal cord at T5
Fasciculus gracilis on the right side of the medulla
Spinothalamic tract left side of the spinal cord at C2

questions.text: A patient has lost the ability to discriminate between two points presented simultaneously to the skin of the left hand. Neurological evaluation is most likely to reveal a lesion in the:
questions.solution:
Medial lemniscus on the right side of the pons

  • Two point discrimination is carried by the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system
  • Dorsal column runs ipsilaterally, while medial lemniscus runs contralateral
  • So, if medial lemniscus is lesioned on the right side, the loss of two point discrimination will be lost on the left side, as observed in this patient.

questions.text: All of the following is a correct match except
questions.solution:
• A – Transverse cervical artery
  • B – Inferior Thyroid Artery
  • C – Vertebral artery
  • D – Subclavian artery

questions.text: Interpeduncular fossa contains all except -
questions.solution:
Contents of interpeduncular fossa :

→ Infundibulum and tuber cinereum

→ Mamillary bodies

→ Posterior Perforated substance

→ Occulomotor nerve

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of external carotid artery in Kisselbach plexus?
questions.solution:
Kiesselbach’s plexus is formed by:

  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery (a branch of ophthalmic artery).
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery (a branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery (a branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (a branch of facial artery)

Ant. and post. ethmoidal are branches of INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY

Maxillary and facial are branches of ECA.

Sphenopalatine artery is ‘artery of epistaxis’.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly marked?
questions.solution:
• A – Fornix
  • B – Lamina Terminalis
  • C – Posterior Commissure
  • D – Hypophysis ( Pituitary Gland)

questions.text: Which of the following structure passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm?
Left superior intercostal vein drains to
questions.solution:
• left superior intercostal vein drains into left brachiocephalic and not into Azygos vein.
  • Right superior intercostal vein, Hemiazygous vein and Accessory hemiazygous vein drains into azygous vein.

questions.text: A schematic of interior part of right atrium is shown. The marked area 'X' develops from;
questions.solution:
• Area marked 'X' is fossa ovalis.
  • Floor of the fossa ovalis is derived from septum primum.
  • Margin or limbus fossa ovalis is derived from septum secundum.

questions.text: Danger space of neck is situated between:
Ejaculatory duct is derived from:
questions.solution:
Derivatives of Wolffian duct/Mesonephric duct :

  • Epididymis
  • Seminal vescicle
  • Ejaculatory duct
  • Ductus deferens

questions.text: Artery lying deep to marked area in the given image is a branch of which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
• Area marked in the given image is Pterion.
  • Artery lying deep to pterion is middle meningeal artery.
  • Middle meningeal artery is a branch of first part of maxillary artery.

questions.text: Nervi Furcalis is related to:
questions.solution: • L4 root bifurcates into 2 parts. One part supplies lumbar plexus. The other part joins with L5 fibres and supply sacral plexus. Hence it is known as nervi furcalis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the special sensory supply for the part of the tongue derived from lingual swellings?
questions.solution:
• lingual swellings forms anterior 2/3rd of tongue.
  • Special sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by chorda tympani branch of facial nerve.
  • General sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by lingual branch or mandibular nerve.

questions.text: Talocalcaneonavicular joint is -
questions.solution:
Ball and Socket Joints :

  • Shoulder or glenohumeral joint
  • Hip joint
  • Talocalcaneonavicular joint
  • Incudostapedial joint

choices.text: A is involved in trendelenburg sign
B passes through greater sciatic foramen
C is a lateral rotator at hip
D is supplied by nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: All are correct statements except
questions.solution:
• A – Gluteus medius muscle which is supplied by superior gluteal nerve (involved in trendelenburg sign)
  • B – Piriformis muscle passing through greater sciatic foramen.
  • C – Gemellus superior muscle helps in lateral rotation at hip joint.
  • D – Gemellus inferior muscle supplied by nerve to quadratus femoris.

questions.text: Short saphenous vein is the continuation of-
questions.solution: • Short saphenous vein is the continuation of Lateral marginal vein

choices.text: Meiosis occurs only after secondary spermatocyte stage

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding spermatogenesis
questions.solution:
• Duration of spermatogenesis is 72-74days.
  • It occurs in seminiferous tubules.
  • Primary spermatocyte converts to secondary spermatocyte by meiosis I.
  • Spermatid forms spermatozoa by spermiogenesis process.

questions.text: Anterior boundary of inguinal canal is formed by muscles -
questions.solution:
Boundaries of inguinal canal :

  • Anterior – External oblique and internal oblique
  • Posterior – Transversalis fascia and conjoint tendon
  • Superior – Internal oblique and transversus abdominis
  • Inferior – Inguinal ligament

choices.text: Above piriformis through Greater Sciatic Foramen
Below piriformis through Greater Sciatic Foramen

questions.text: Nerve involved in the given condition passes through -
questions.solution:
• Given condition in the image is lurching gait (Trendelenburg sign positive).
  • Nerve involved in this condition is superior gluteal nerve which passes through greater sciatic foramen above piriformis.

questions.text: Structure which passes through both greater and lesser sciatic foramen?
questions.solution:
Structures Passing through Greater Sciatic Foramen

Above Piriformis – Superior Gluteal nerve, artery and vein.

Below Piriformis – Inferior Gluteal nerve, artery and vein

– Nerve to Obturator Internus

– Nerve to Quadratus Femoris

– Sciatic Nerve

– Pudendal nerve

– Internal Pudendal artery and vein

– Nerve to obturator internus

Structures Passing through Lesser Sciatic Foramen

– Pudendal Nerve

– Internal Pudendal artery and vein

– Obturator Internus muscle

– Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Coracoid process is a kind of epiphysis
questions.solution:
Atavistic Epiphysis

Examples : Coracoid process of scapula and Ostrigonum.

questions.text: Root value of nerve involved in Meralgia paraesthesia is -
questions.solution:
• Nerve involved in meralgia paresthesia is lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh originates from L2 and L3 and is entraped beneath the inguinal ligament in this condition.

questions.text: Muscle attached to arrow marked in given image
questions.solution:
• Arrow marked structure is lesser trochanter.
  • Iliacus and psoas major muscle inserts on lesser trochanter.

choices.text: Loss of sensation from the floor of mouth
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue

questions.text: Which of the following clinical finding is not seen in lesions of structures passing through jugular foramen:
questions.solution:
• Structures passing through jugular foramen are Cranial nerve IX, X and XI.
  • Lesion to these structures doesn’t involve loss of sensation from the floor of mouth.

questions.text: Safety muscle of larynx:
questions.solution:
• A – Posterior Cricoarytenoid
  • B – Cricothyroid
  • C – Lateral Cricoarytenoid
  • D – Transverse arytenoid
  • Safety muscle of larynx is posterior cricoarytenoid (only abductor of vocal cords)

choices.text: Deep petrosal nerve + greater petrosal nerve
Greater petrosal nerve + Lesser Petrosal nerve
Deep Petrosal nerve + Lesser Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: Nerve to pterygoid canal/ vidian nerve is formed by :
questions.solution: • Nerve to pterygoid canal or vidians nerve is formed by greater petrosal nerve and deep petrosal nerve.

choices.text: Chorda tympani in the middle ear cavity

questions.text: A 46-year-old man complains of dryness of the mouth. On examination he lack salivary secretion from the submandibular gland. This indicates a lesion of which of the following nervous structures?
questions.solution: • Chorda tympani carries the salivatory fibres to Submandibular gland and sublingual gland.

questions.text: After tonsillectomy, Pain in post 1/3rd of tongue is due to injury to
questions.solution: • Glossopharyngeal nerve carries both general sensation as well as special sensation from posterior 1/3rd of tongue.

choices.text: Arch of aorta in between left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery

questions.text: Fate of 6th aortic arch:
questions.solution:
• Proximal part of 6th arch artery forms pulmonary artery.
  • Distal part of left 6th arch artery forms ductus arteriosus

choices.text: Most commonly involved in intracranial aneurysm

questions.text: All are correct about the Cranial nerve that lies between superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery except
questions.solution:
• Occulomotor nerve passes between superior cerebellar artery and Posterior cerebral artery.
  • Occulomotor nerve is the most common to be involved in intracranial aneurysm.
  • It is a content of interpeducular fossa.
  • It supplies to all the extraocular muscles except superior oblique and lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: A young patient with absent thymus and presented with hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following is defective?
questions.solution:
• Thymus and inferior parathyroid gland are derived from 3rd pharyngeal pouch.
  • Superior parathyroid gland is derived from 4th pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: The type of joint present between Epiphysis & Diaphysis is
questions.solution:
Pimary cartilaginous joint/Synchondrosis

Examples :

  • Between epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone (Epiphyseal plate)
  • All costochondral joints
